subject: Re: [junit] Testing methods declared private

messageBody:
Peter,

private is private - so if these methods truly are private then noone can
get at them.

However, one technique is to use an inner class that gives access to the
methods to be tested, and then to not include that class when publishing the
final code.

For example, here is some class with a private method (I've attached the
classes too, in case this gets garbled as text)

public class PrivateMethod
{
private String value = "foo";

private String getValue(){
return value;
}

private void setValue(String v){
this.value = v;
}

public class Test
{
public String getValue(){
return value;
}
public void setValue(String v){
value = v;
}
}
}
Note the inner "Test" class exposing public versions of the private get/set
methods ...

Here's a TestPrivateMethod class which will show how to use the inner
PrivateMethod.Test class:

import junit.framework.TestCase;
import junit.framework.TestSuite;
import junit.textui.TestRunner;

public class TestPrivateMethod extends TestCase
{

public TestPrivateMethod(String name){
super(name);
}

public static void main(String [] args){
TestRunner.run(new TestSuite(TestPrivateMethod.class));
}

/** Will not compile!
public void testPrivateGet(){
PrivateMethod p = new PrivateMethod();
assertEquals(p.getValue(), "foo");
}
*/

public void testPrivateGetViaInnerClass(){
PrivateMethod p = new PrivateMethod();
PrivateMethod.Test pt = p.new Test();
assertEquals("foo", pt.getValue());
}

public void testPrivateSetViaInnerClass(){
PrivateMethod p = new PrivateMethod();
PrivateMethod.Test pt = p.new Test();
final String nv = "new value";
pt.setValue(nv);
assertEquals( nv, pt.getValue());
}
}
